awd_titl_txt: Women in Noncommutative Algebra and Representation Theory Workshop 3
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the participation of US-based researchers in the workshop WINART3, Women in Noncommutative Algebra and Representation Theory, held at the Banff International Research Station, Banff, Canada on April 3-8, 2022. The goal of the workshop is to bring together experts and junior participants working in these fields to collaborate on research projects, and its primary focus is to facilitate research activities. There will be eight research groups consisting of four to six participants, each led by two research leaders. Each group will come to the workshop with a prepared plan and project and spend most of the workshop working on their respective projects. The workshop will also feature several introductory, as well as more advanced, talks, and professional development activities. This structure was very successful in previous workshops in the series: WINART1 in 2016 and WINART2 in 2019.

The fields of noncommutative algebra and representation theory have long been closely intertwined, but even more so since the emergence of quantum groups in the 1980s. The results in these fields have been significant in their own right and also have had a strong influence in shaping other fields such as conformal field theory, the study of operator algebras, string theory, topological field theory, and the various forms of noncommutative geometry. There will be a variety of research topics present at the WINART3 workshop: cluster theory, Hopf algebras and their representation theory, weak Hopf algebras and their actions on algebras, infinite-dimensional Lie theory, and Hochschild cohomology. The workshop website is: https://women-in-ncalg-repthy.org/conferences/winart3-workshop/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The workshop Women in Noncommutative Algebra and Representation Theory 3 (WINART 3) was held at the Banff International Research Station in Banff, Canada, on April 4 - April 8, 2022. There were 8 groups consisting of 3-5 members. Each group worked together on a problem of their choice, first by getting ready with the necessary background before the meeting, then working together during the week at Banff, and continuing the work after that. Due to pandemic, some of the groups preferred remote work together, however the WINART 3 was still their motivating workshop.

The goals of WINART 3 were: to give opportunities for experts and junior participants to work together on research problems, to encourage and support members of underrepresented groups to join and do the research in noncommutative algebra and representation theory, and also to provide networking opportunities and mentoring for its participants at and beyond the workshop. The first two WINART workshops were very successful and had great impact on the research careers as well as the development of the entire research area. The same is expected now from WINART 3.

Our research groups worked on several topics, sometimes related to each other, and sometimes related to other areas of mathematics. Our experts on Hopf algebras and fusion categories worked on the fusion relations on Hopf algebras, as a special case of fusion relations in fusion categories. Three of the groups worked on the popular cluster topics: geometric interpretations of cluster notions, and also on the combinatorial notions of friezes. Friezes are interesting from the combinatorial point of view, but are also closely related to cluster structures. Another group worked on the structure of the Monster Lie algebra, which was constructed in order to deal with the Conway-Norton Monstrous Moonshine Conjecture. Two groups were working on the highly popular Hochschild (co)homologies for the classes of gentle and string algebras, which are special monomial algebras. Generalized Quantum Symmetry via Hopf algebroids is a beautiful generalization of the classical notions of symmetry as a transformation of an object to itself, or more algebraically, as an action of an algebraic object on another. So categorical properties of representations of Hopf algebroids are studied by one of our research groups as an interpretation of the generalized quantum symmetry.

Products resulting from the workshop to date: two papers posted on math arxiv: "Maurer-Cartan equation for gentle algebras" by Monique Muller, Maria Julia Redondo, and Pamela Suarez, https://arxiv.org/abs/2309.02582 and "Vertex operators for imaginary gl2 subalgebras of the Monster Lie algebra" by Darlayne Addabbo, Lisa Carbone, Elizabeth Jurisich, Maryam Khaqan, and Scott H. Murray, https://arxiv.org/pdf/2210.16178.pdf. Furthermore the second paper already in- spired the work on the next paper as a continuation. Several other group papers are also close to being posted.
